turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You have to come to my dad's lobster pound and see one, then.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Okay...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I better go.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I don't think Mr. Rose would leave without you.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: A movie *outside*?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Yes. But it's closed all the time now, because of the blackout.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: People watched the movies in their cars?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: When they watched at all. Do you like movies?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Yes! I've only seen one, though.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You've seen only one movie? Which one?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "King Kong". It's really good.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: But you looked as if you liked it.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I *did* like it. All I said was, "It's not 'King Kong'."

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: First she loved him, then she didn't, then no one else could have him...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: She *did* love him!  How many women have you known?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: And what did she die of, exactly?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: She was torn apart! She died of a broken heart.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Oh, sure!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What's the *medical* explanation?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Well, she was in a weakened condition...  I don't know! What about "King Kong"?! Is that medically possible?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You're a natural. You were born to drive a car like this.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You think? Maybe I was.  I love this place!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: The screen is enormous! Imagine King Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot of movies here?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Yes... and no. When you come here, you don't really care about the movie.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: What are you so crazy about the movies for?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It was my favorite night at the orphanage--movie night. We'd race into the dining hall. Of course everyone wanted to sit in front, so we'd be packed in so tight you could feel the kid next to you breathing.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: At least you were never lonely.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I didn't say that. Growing up in an orphanage, you're always lonely. You're just never alone.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You don't miss it?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I miss things. I miss... people.  I miss reading to the boys.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: But you had so much *responsibility*.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I never *asked* for any responsibility.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Just a little privacy.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Did you come here with Wally--to *not* watch movies?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Ah-ha.  So what is that--a radio?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: The *speaker*. For the movie sound.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: How could you not *care* about the movie?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You just cuddle. You come to hug... to kiss. You don't *come* here to watch the movie.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd watch the movie.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Not with the right girl you wouldn't.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Aren't you worried that people will cut their feet?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Nobody will swim here until next summer. By then, the water will have rubbed the glass smooth against the sand--there won't be any sharp edges.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I *know* this was right.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Just tell me. Do you want me to go? Do you want me to stay?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: It will be okay.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: *What* will be okay?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: We have to wait and see. I think that, for *everything* in life, you have to wait and see.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Olive told me.  You might have told me yourself.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm just waiting and seeing. Like you said.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Do you think I'm having a good time? Do you think I'm just *teasing* you? Do you think I *know* whether I want you or Wally?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: So we should "wait and see." For how long?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I grew up with Wally. I began my adult life with him.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Fine. That's all there is to it then.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No! That's not all there is to it! I love you, too--I *know* I do.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Okay, okay--I know you do, too.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: It's a good thing I didn't have that baby, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: We should take her to St. Cloud's. That much is obvious, isn't it? Let her make up her mind when she gets there...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I told her! She doesn't feel she can do that. Something about her father not letting her go anywhere...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Well, we have to help her!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: She won't go to St. Cloud's!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Well, we can't force her. It's her decision.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You don't understand! It's her father...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Mr. Rose *knows*?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: He's the *father*! He's her baby's father!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Wait... *wait*! Are you sure?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: We've got to keep her away from that bastard!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Just tell me. I'll do whatever you want to do.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Isn't that like waiting and seeing?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No. Nothing is nothing. I want Wally to come home. I'm afraid to see him, too.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know.  Is *that* nothing.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No, don't--that's something. Nothing is nothing.  Don't even look at me. I want...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Please don't move, don't go anywhere.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: *Go* anywhere? Of course not! That would be *doing* something, wouldn't it? We wouldn't want to *do* something. Let's just sit here all night!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: If you're trying to be funny, Homer...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm not trying to be anything--I'm just doing nothing! If I wait and see long enough, then--with any luck-- I won't *ever* have to make up my mind! Decisions can be painful, after all...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Stop it! Just cut it out!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You got up! You *did* something! If you keep this up, you might be in danger of making a *decision*!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: For God's sake, Homer, Wally's been shot down!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: He's *paralyzed*!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: He's *alive*. He still loves you.  So do I.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: What do you want me to *do*?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Please don't make me say it again.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No, that's not it--I just want to be sure I understand you.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I *helped* you not to think about Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't stand worrying about him, about his being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could stop worrying... well, for a while, anyway. This is how I helped you, right?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Please... that's enough. I *loved* you, too--you know I did.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "...did." Well, okay.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Please don't...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: And now that Wally's coming back, and because he'll certainly *need* you...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You say that as though it's some awful thing!  I never stopped loving Wally!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Do you think she'll be all right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: She knows how to take care of herself.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: This came for you a couple of days ago. Olive asked me to bring it. With everything happening, I guess she forgot.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Sure. Thanks.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I know you don't think much of being needed, or of me for that matter...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm sorry for what I said about Wally needing you. It was... unnecessary.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No, I'm the one who should be sorry. You have every right to be angry.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No. You warned me. I didn't listen, but you warned me.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: How is that Wally doing?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Oh, he's fine! I just heard from him. He's bombing all these places...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Hi...

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: Hi...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I've got some more clothes for you-- I just keep forgetting to bring them with me.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: I don't need no more clothes, thank you.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Rose, I know what's going on. Homer told me. I got pregnant, too--about a year ago.  I've been through this.

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: You ain't been through what I been through, Candy.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Yes, I *have*!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I know where you can go. Homer and I can take you...

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: I can't go nowhere.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You can trust me. Is it Jack? It's not Jack, is it? It's *Muddy*! Is it Muddy?

turns.speaker: ROSE ROSE
turns.text: No. It ain't Muddy. Muddy's just...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: So many children. Are they all orphans?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Well, this *is* an orphanage.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I'm okay--I can walk.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I don't want you to walk--I want to carry you. Should I put the top up? It might get cold.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No--keep it down. I want to feel the air.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Wally thinks apples are boring.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I never said they were boring.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You said, "Apples aren't exactly flying."

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Well, they aren't.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: There! You said it was boring.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Well, *picking* them is! It's about as exciting as... walking!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I love you, Wally.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I love you, too. See you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I was just showing Homer the orchards... kind of a geography lesson.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I know what you've been doing.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: You've been giving him a *flying* lesson!

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: He *loved* it!  Didn't you?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: He thinks people *like* to get whacked by branches.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: *Homer* liked it!  Didn't you?

turns.speaker: CURLY
turns.text: I thought they might take me.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: They wanted a girl.

turns.speaker: CURLY
turns.text: Nobody ever wants me!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You're one of the best, Curly--we couldn't let just anyone take you.

turns.speaker: CURLY
turns.text: Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone take *any* of us!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: That's true.

turns.speaker: CURLY
turns.text: Nobody's asked for me, have they?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Nobody special enough, Curly.

turns.speaker: CURLY
turns.text: You mean somebody asked?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Only the right people can have you, Curly.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Her temperature is a hundred and four.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: How old are you, dear? Thirteen?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: That's a heavy sedation.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You *bet* it's a heavy sedation! The fetus is unexpelled, her uterus is punctured, she has acute peritonitis, and there's a foreign object. I think it's a crochet hook.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I don't know! He's just leaving--  you're the one who says he needs to see the world!  *That's* what he'll do--he'll see the world!

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: He's leaving...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: "Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine, March 2, 1915..."

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Homer was born *here*, in, what was it, 1922?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: "...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935, and Harvard School of Medicine, 1939."

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: You mean they'll replace you with someone who won't perform abortions.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Well, we can only guess about that, Edna. They *are* against the law.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: So here is my candidate. What do you think?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: But what about school records? Homer doesn't have any *diplomas*...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Or that he can't be bothered to write us a proper letter? A dissertation on apples, we don't need!

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: He probably doesn't make much money picking apples--he must have had to pay to send them, too.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he doesn't have money. If he gets hungry, he can pick his dinner!

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: I just wanted to ask you...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Edna! Come dance with me! Let's be foolish tonight.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Does he *know* he's supposed to be in India? Does he even *want* to come back?

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Is *your* father dead?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the liver.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: *Liver* killed him?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: *Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself to death.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: But did you know him?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Barely. It hardly mattered that I knew him.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Did you know your mother better?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: What's a nanny do?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: She looks after other people's children.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Did you grow up around here?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: No. She was an immigrant.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: What's an immigrant?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Someone not from Maine.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Homer... doesn't King Kong think the woman is his *mother*?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Uh, sure--that's what Kong thinks, all right.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: That's why Kong loves her!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "I was a posthumous child. My father's eyes had closed upon the light of this world six months, when mine opened on it."

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: His father's dead, right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Uh... it's the end of October.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Is that soon?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.

turns.speaker: FUZZY
turns.text: Why can't we have pumpkins for Christmas, too? We don't get any good presents at Christmas, anyway.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Did you bite it?

turns.speaker: MARY AGNES
turns.text: I don't remember.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It looks like you bit it--it'll be all right.

turns.speaker: MARY AGNES
turns.text: Maybe I was kissing someone and he bit me.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No, you did it yourself. Maybe in your sleep.

turns.speaker: MARY AGNES
turns.text: I must have been *dreaming* of kissing someone.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm sorry. They're not used to seeing a car like this.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: It's okay--I don't mind.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: So, now, uh... you're not... I mean, do *you* do the--

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No. Dr. Larch will be performing the procedure.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Ah, well... okay. Good! I just wondered...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What kind of plane are you flying?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: A B-24 Liberator.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Liberator...

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Have you enlisted?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Really! Is it serious?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No, it's not serious. I'm just not supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep calm all the time.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Has anyone offered you anything to eat?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Actually, someone did. I just didn't think I could eat anything.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I wonder if you might give me a ride.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I think I'd probably like the apple business.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: You're a little overqualified, aren't you?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: No, I'm not. I need a job.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: The only jobs are picking jobs. Picking apples is truly boring.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: This is all normal. Don't worry. The abortion procedure... it affects you. It's the ether, too. It'll take a little time.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I don't *have* any time. There's a *war*!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It's all very normal.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: "Burma run" because you fly over Burma...

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: *And* over the Himalayas. That's called flying over the hump.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: At what altitude?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I've got thirty-five minutes to climb to fifteen thousand feet--that's the first mountain pass.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What lousy luck--I mean your orders... to draw an assignment like that!

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Actually, I volunteered.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Uh, look... if you're serious about wanting a job, picking apples isn't that boring.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Oh, I would love that, Wally.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: They're migrants.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Migrants?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Yes. They pick fruit, all kinds. They travel up and down the coast with the seasons.  The trick to Mr. Rose is, you have to let him be the boss.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: It's almost like flying.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What about the trees?

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: The trees are flak--antiaircraft fire from those geeks on the ground.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I thought. I just wanted to be sure you were settled in--and happy enough, considering...  Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick it out for a bit?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Uh... actually, picking apples is as much excitement as I want for a while. I'm grateful for the job.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: You're the one who's helping *me*, Homer. You're going to give my mom a little peace of mind while I'm gone. Candy, too.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Well, sure... that's good, then.  All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.

turns.speaker: WALLY
turns.text: I don't think so, Homer. *I'm* the lucky one.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: So. What should I do now?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Out back, there's a shed. It's just a mess. If that shed was better organized, I could put my truck in there.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: It's big enough to keep you out of the war, I suppose. Ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Stop it, Homer. They aren't our rules. We didn't write them. I don't see no reason to read them.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Okay...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That's better. I can tell you got yourself some education. Them's good hands you got, Homer. Them hands you got, they know what they're doin'-- ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I guess so...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Are we supposed to be up here? The rules said...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Homer, you the only one who's read them rules, so you the only one who feels like he's doin' somethin' wrong.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Cider don't have no taste till later in October--it's too watery now, when we're usin' just them early Macs and them Gravensteins. You don't get no *good* cider till you're pickin' them Golden Delicious and them Winter Bananas, them Baldwins and them Russerts...

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What about the worms? Most of these apples are the drops--off the ground, right? There have to be worms.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Of *course* there's worms, Homer! And what is them worms, really? They just *protein*, them worms! They is *good* for you!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Slow down, Homer--don't be in such a big hurry.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: This is easy--I'm not hurrying.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You still doin' it too fast!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: I didn't see where you was pickin' this mornin', Homer, but you musta worked up a big appetite. You look like you're serious about gettin' to your lunch today!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: I think you been stayin' up too late at night, Homer.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You're actually having sex with your own little girl? Is that possible?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Ain't nobody havin' *sex* with my little girl, Homer--that's somethin' a father knows.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You're lying. How can you... with your own daughter!

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Homer, don't you know what business you in? You don't wanna go into no business with me, Homer--ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Go on, cut my clothes. I've got other clothes.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: But she's your *daughter*...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: And I *love* her! There ain't nobody else gonna treat her as good as I do!  I wouldn't do nothin' to hurt her, Homer--you must know that.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Please listen to me! *Both* of you...

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: You forget yourself, Homer. This here's my daughter! You got your own mess to deal with--ain't that right?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: What business is you in, Homer?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Mr. Rose, I'm in the *doctor* business.  If you want, I can help you. You don't have to go anywhere.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: What's that? What's it called?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: One cervical stabilizer, two sets of dilators--Douglas points. One medium- sized curette, one small; one medium speculum, one large; two vulsellum forceps.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: There ain't no *almost* about this stuff, Homer--ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Merthiolate, ether, vulval pads, gauze--lots of gauze.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: When it comes to this, you is the real thing--is that what you sayin'?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: I'm stayin', Homer.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Okay. Then you can be of use.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: If that was your knife, Muddy, I wanna thank you for givin' it to her-- no girl should be goin' *hitch-hikin'* if she don't got a good knife with her.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Where'd she get you?

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: She just plan misunderstand me--I was tryin' to give her my knife, I was just reachin' to touch her hand. But I understand if she misunderstand me--it's all my fault, ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: There's more than one laceration, more than one cut.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: That's 'cause I sticked my *own* knife in the wound--after she go, I sticked my *own* knife in there. I poked it all around, I just tryin' to find the same place she got me.

turns.speaker: MR. ROSE
turns.text: Let me hear you say that! I so unhappy she runned away that I killed myself-- that what happen here, ain't that right?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Right?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: First pregnancy?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Yes, for both.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I presume you'd prefer handling the delivery.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: All I said was, I don't want to perform abortions. I have no argument with *you* performing them.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to help them when they can't get help anywhere else?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: One: it's illegal. Two: I didn't ask how to do it--you just showed me.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: What *else* could I have showed you, Homer? The only thing I can teach you is what I know! In every life, you've got to be of use.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: There was no visible wound?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus was virtually *disintegrating*--my stitches pulled right through the tissue!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It looks like scurvy.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Scurvy! Ah yes, the curse of the old- time sailor, suffering long periods at sea with no fresh fruits or vegetables. Homer, Dorothy isn't a *sailor*!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It's obviously an aborticide.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Obviously.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Christ, it's oil of tansy!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I don't know it.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: If you take enough of it, your intestines lose their ability to absorb Vitamin C.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: In other words, scurvy.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Good boy. Good job. And you call yourself "not a doctor"!  Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you, there's something about the premature babies of alcoholic mothers. They seem susceptible to every damn thing that comes along.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I haven't read that.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I haven't, either. But you *will*. The morons who write the books should do a little research *here*.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: But isn't Fuzzy just... well, underdeveloped?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I wouldn't call his bronchial infections "underdeveloped." Would you?
